questions.text: Match Column A with B
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

1. Pterygopalatine ganglion → Greater petrosal nerve (b): Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers come from the greater petrosal nerve (branch of facial nerve) and synapse in the pterygopalatine ganglion. Postganglionic fibers supply the lacrimal gland and nasal glands.

2. Otic ganglion → Lesser petrosal nerve (a): Preganglionic fibers travel via the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and its branch, the lesser petrosal nerve, to the otic ganglion. Postganglionic fibers then join the auriculotemporal nerve to supply the parotid gland.

3. Submandibular ganglion → Chorda tympani (e): Preganglionic fibers come via the chorda tympani (branch of facial nerve) which joins the lingual nerve. Postganglionic fibers innervate the submandibular and sublingual glands.

4. Ciliary ganglion → Nerve to inferior oblique (f): Preganglionic fibers come from the oculomotor nerve (via the nerve to inferior oblique). Postganglionic fibers from the ciliary ganglion travel via short ciliary nerves to the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle.

questions.text: Following statements about trigeminal nerve is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

is true, ABD are false Explanation:
•    The trigeminal nerve is the largest CN
•    Has 3 divisions: Ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular (largest division)
•    The motor nucleus is ventromedial to the sensory nucleus. It lies near the lateral angle of the fourth ventricle in the rostral part of the pons. The mesencephalic nucleus is in the midbrain and receives proprioceptive ﬁbers from all muscles of mastication.
•    The ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve leave the skull through 3 separate foramina: the superior orbital ﬁssure, the foramen rotundum, and the foramen ovale, respectively
•    The ophthalmic nerve carries sensory information from the scalp and forehead, the upper eyelid, the conjunctiva and cornea of the eye, the tip of the nose, the nasal mucosa, the frontal sinuses, and parts of the meninges (the dura and blood vessels).
•    The maxillary nerve carries sensory information from the lower eyelid and cheek, the nares and upper lip, the upper teeth and gums, the nasal mucosa, the palate and roof of the pharynx, the maxillary, ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses, and parts of the meninges
•    The mandibular nerve carries sensory information from the lower lip, the lower teeth, gums, the chin and jaw (except the angle of the mandible, which is supplied by C2-C3), parts of the external ear, and parts of the meninges

questions.text: A 25 years old man is involved in an automobile accident and slams his head into a concrete wall of a bridge. His CT scan reveals that the middle meningeal artery has ruptured but the meninges remain intact. Blood leaking from this artery enters which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The middle meningeal artery runs between the dura mater and the skull. When it ruptures, typically due to a temporal bone fracture, blood accumulates between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. This produces an epidural hematoma, classically associated with a “lucid interval” followed by rapid neurological deterioration. The meninges remain intact in this situation, as the bleed is external to the dura.

questions.text:
Read the Following statements regarding blood supplyA aneurysm involving which of the artery is most likely responsible for this patients symptoms ?

A.    Primary Motor area – MCA, ACA

B.    Primary Sensory area – MCA, ACA

C.    Macula – MCA, PCA

D.    Speech area– MCA
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All are correct 

<!--[if !supportLists]-->·       <!--[endif]-->Primary motor area (precentral gyrus): MCA & ACA. Lateral homunculus (face/upper limb) is supplied by the MCA, while the medial paracentral lobule (leg/foot) is supplied by the ACA—hence both vessels supply the primary motor cortex.

<!--[if !supportLists]-->·       <!--[endif]-->Primary sensory area (postcentral gyrus): MCA & ACA. The same lateral–medial somatotopy applies to the primary somatosensory cortex; thus MCA (lateral body) and ACA (medial leg) both contribute.

<!--[if !supportLists]-->·      <!--[endif]-->Macula: MCA & PCA. The primary visual cortex is PCA-dependent, but the macular region receives dual (MCA + PCA) collateral supply—this explains macular sparing in many PCA infarcts.

<!--[if !supportLists]-->·         <!--[endif]-->Speech area: MCA. Broca’s (inferior frontal gyrus) and Wernicke’s (posterior superior temporal gyrus) areas lie in the dominant hemisphere MCA territory.

2.    Brachial artery

questions.text: Main action of marked muscle on the TM joint in the below image is ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The arrow in the image points to the lateral pterygoid muscle. This is the only muscle of mastication that primarily acts to depress the mandible (open the mouth) at the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). It also assists in protraction and produces side-to-side (lateral) movements when acting unilaterally. Its unique role in depression distinguishes it from the other muscles of mastication, which are mainly elevators.

questions.text:
Some mucopolysaccharidoses cause only connective tissue problems. In others, however, the patients have mental deficiency. Mental deficiency is most likely to occur in diseases with impaired breakdown of heparan sulfate, which is accumulated in

1.    Hurler syndrome

2.    San Filippo syndrome

3.    Morquio syndrome

4.    Maroteux lamy syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1,2


1.    Defects in the degradation of keratan sulfate and dermatan sulfate cause skeletal deformities and other
connective tissue abnormalities. Typical abnormalities include coarse facial features (“gargoylism”), short
 
stature, corneal clouding, hearing loss, stiff joints, valvular heart disease, obstructive lung disease, and hepatosplenomegaly.
2.    Defects in the degradation of heparan sulfate cause mental retardation and neurological degeneration. Heparan sulfate is the only important GAG in the central nervous system.
3.    Chondroitin sulfate and hyaluronic acid do not accumulate.

They can be degraded by a lysosomal endoglycosidase when one of the exoglycosidases is missing.
4.    HS is accumulated in Hurler ,Hunter, Sly, Sanfilippo syndromes

questions.text:
In response to a large mixed meal, the number of glucose transporters in the plasma membrane increases most markedly in which one of the following cell types?
 
1.    Adipocyte
2.    Hepatocyte
3.    Intestinal epithelial cell
4.    Muscles
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1,4

The correct response is adipocytes and muscle cells, because both contain insulin-sensitive GLUT-4 transporters. After a large mixed meal, blood glucose rises and insulin is secreted. Insulin stimulates the translocation of GLUT-4 transporters from intracellular vesicles to the plasma membrane, thereby increasing glucose uptake into these cells. This process is crucial for postprandial glucose regulation:

  • In muscle cells, glucose is stored as glycogen or used immediately for energy.
  • In adipocytes, glucose is converted into glycerol and fatty acids for triglyceride storage.
    This insulin-mediated GLUT-4 translocation is the most marked and physiologically important change following a meal.

questions.text: A 16-year-old teenager boy presents with moderate to severe epigastric pain. Physical examination reveals extensive eruptive xanthomas and hepatosplenomegaly. A blood sample reveals milky plasma. Which of the following is the most likely lipoprotein to be elevated in the plasma of this patient accounting for the milky appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

chylomicrons -.Given is a case of type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia ,which present with acute pancreatitis due to raised TG >1000mg/dl deficiency of apo CII or LPL enzyme - Chylomicrons are assembled in the intestinal mucosa as a means to transport dietary cholesterol and triglycerides to the rest of the body. Chylomicrons leave the intestine via the lymphatic system and enter the circulation at the left subclavian vein. High levels of chylomicrons in the blood can give it a milky appearance. The term chyle refers to the milky fluid consisting of lymph and emulsified fats or free fatty acids, which is how the term chylomicron was derived.

questions.text:
Which of the following are derivatives of amino acids

1. Histamine and Dopamine

2. Haem and carnitine

3. Melanin and melatonin

4. NAD and glutathione
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1,2,3,4

All the listed compounds are indeed derived from amino acids:

• Histamine is derived from histidine (via decarboxylation).
• Dopamine is derived from tyrosine (via L-DOPA intermediate).
• Haem is synthesized from glycine and succinyl-CoA (porphyrin pathway).
• Carnitine is derived from lysine and methionine.
• Melanin comes from tyrosine (via dopaquinone pathway).
• Melatonin is derived from tryptophan (via serotonin).
• NAD⁺ (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) is derived from tryptophan.
• Glutathione is a tripeptide synthesized from glutamate, cysteine, and glycine, all of which are amino acids.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child present with red scaly painful rash on sun exposed areas, frequent mood swings and unsteady gait. Urinalysis show gross neutral aminoaciduria, with exception of proline and glycine. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hartnup disease Answer is HARTNUP dis :a combination of pellagra like dermatosis ,ataxia and neutral aminoaciduria 1. Neutral amino acids are aka mono amino mono carboxylic acids. E.g. Glycine, Alanine, leucine, Isoleucine, valine, phenylalanine, Proline, methionine, serine, threonine, tyrosine, cysteine, tryptophan. 2. But transporter of proline and glycine (defective in iminoglycinuria) is separate and so of the cysteine (basic amino acid transporter). 3. Hartnup is defective transporter of neutral amino acids notably tryptophan. This transporter called B(0)AT1 is coded by SLC6A19 gene, and expressed in intestine and PCT of the kidney. So poor abs and excess excretion result in low TRYPTOPHAN:pellagra like dermatosis (as in our MCQ). 4. Intermittent ataxia is
 
other major C/F. (also seen in MSUD but no TRYP in urine ) 5. Diagnosis : amino aciduria all the above mentioned .Absence of proline and glycine differentiate Hartnup from other generalized aminoaciduria like Fanconi syndrome. 6. Obermeyer test (tryptophan load) give positive result which detects indole compounds in urine. 7. Treatment: High protein diet, supplement of nicotinic acid (50-300 mg/24 hr), supplement of lipid soluble esters of neutral amino acids and ethyl esters of tryptophan 8. Tyrosinemia type II (Oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia or Richner Hanhart Syndrome) It is due to deficiency of the tyrosine transaminase. Ocular features are earliest to be detected, herpetic- like corneal ulcerations are found. Palmoplantar hyperkeratosis is a specific feature.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Her 24-hour uric acid excretion is found to be 1.3 gram. Reduced activity of which enzyme could plausibly cause her hyperuricemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase - Urinary excretion in
 
excess of 600 mg/day is evidence of uric acid overproduction. From 15% to 25% of patients with primary gout are overproducers; the other 75% to 85% of patients have reduced renal clearance of uric acid. - Abnormalities of two enzymes have been identified in a minority of patients with uric acid overproduction 1- Overactivity of PRPP synthetase increases de novo purine biosynthesis, and purine breakdown must rise in proportion. Elevated levels of IMP, GMP, and AMP from increased de novo biosynthesis inhibit the salvage enzymes and thereby favor uric acid formation over recycling 2- Reduced activity of the salvage enzyme HPRT causes hyperuricemia because the substrates of the deficient enzyme accumulate, whereas the levels of its products are reduced: • The cellular levels of the free bases are increased, thus, providing more substrate for uric acid synthesis. • The cellular PRPP level is increased because of decreased consumption in the salvage reactions, and more substrate is available for the PRPP amidotransferase of the de novo pathway. • The cellular concentrations of the nucleotides are reduced. This disinhibits the regulated enzymes of the de novo pathway. The result is an increased rate of de novo synthesis, balanced by an equally increased rate of uric acid formation.

questions.text: An infant is diagnosed with lactic acidosis due to impaired function of pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. In terms of diet which of the following is considered safe ,so that will not worsen the condition of patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The safe dietary component for an infant with pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDH) deficiency is leucine. PDH normally converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA. When this enzyme is defective, pyruvate accumulates and is shunted into lactate, causing lactic acidosis. To prevent worsening acidosis, dietary sources that generate pyruvate must be avoided.

• Leucine is a strictly ketogenic amino acid; it is metabolized directly into acetyl-CoA and acetoacetate, bypassing pyruvate formation. Thus, it does not increase pyruvate or lactate levels, making it safe.

questions.text:
A deep-sea diver is given a helium-oxygen mixture rather than nitrogen-oxygen mixture (with the same oxygen concentration) during his dive to a depth of 100m. Which of the following statements is true? (multiple true/ false)
A.    Risk of decompression sickness is decreased
B.    Work of breathing is increased
C.    Airway resistance is increased
D.    Risk of O2 toxicity is decreased 
E.    Risk of inert gas narcosis is decreased
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
A- true; B- false; C- false; D- false; E- true
A is true because decompression sickness is caused by the formation of gas bubbles when the diver comes to the surface. Helium is a much less soluble gas as compared to nitrogen, so the risk of gas emboli is significantly less. 

Helium being a less dense gas than nitrogen, work of breathing and airway resistance are both decreased. The risk of O2 toxicity is unchanged, but the risk of inert gas narcosis is decreased.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding acclimatization at high altitude? (multiple true/ false)
A.    Hyperventilation is of little value
B.    Polycythemia occurs rapidly
C.    There is a rightward shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve
D.    Number of capillaries per unit volume in skeletal muscle decreases
E.    Changes in oxidative enzymes occurs inside muscle cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
A- false; B- false; C- true; D- false; E- true
A is incorrect. Hyperventilation is the most important feature of acclimatization.
B is incorrect. Polycythemia occurs slowly. 
C is correct. Respiratory alkalosis at high altitude can cause a leftward shift of the OHDC but a simultaneous increase in 2,3-BPG causes a net rightward shift of the OHDC. 
D is incorrect. The number of capillaries per unit volume of skeletal muscle increases with acclimatization. 
E is correct. Hypoxia at high altitude increases the oxidative enzymes and oxidative capacity of skeletal muscles.

questions.text: The patient appears dehydrated, and the plasma osmolality is 320 mOsm/kg. During a water deprivation test there was little increase in urine osmolarity after 6 hours. Desmopressin injection had little effect. Plasma and kidney tissue analysis would be expected to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
Increased levels of ADH and decreased V2 receptor activity
In the presence of ADH, aquaporin channels are inserted into the apical membrane, allowing the osmotically driven reabsorption of water. ADH increases tubular fluid osmolality in the late distal tubule and cortical collecting duct to 300 mOsm/L, equal to the renal cortex interstitium osmolality. In the medullary collecting duct, ADH increases tubular fluid osmolality up to the level of the renal medullary interstitium osmolality, up to 1400 mOsm/L in a dehydrated individual. ADH results in the production of a small volume of highly concentrated urine.
Diabetes insipidus is characterized by excretion of large volumes of extremely dilute urine. It can be “neurogenic” or “nephrogenic”. In neurogenic DI, there is a decreased production of ADH. “Nephrogenic” indicates the problem is the renal response to ADH, not the production of ADH. Plasma ADH levels are usually high, reflecting the ADH releasing stimulus, high plasma osmolality.
If the 24-hour urine collection shows a dilute urine, the diagnosis is confirmed with the water deprivation test. A normal individual should increase the urine osmolarity when water is withheld.

The absence of an increase in urine osmolarity indicates impairment in water reabsorption. Injection of desmopressin should result in an increase in urine osmolarity if the kidneys are able to respond to ADH and is used to distinguish central diabetes insipidus from nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man arrived by ambulance at the emergency department after an industrial accident that cut the femoral artery, causing the loss of 1.5 L of blood. Bleeding was controlled by direct pressure, and the patient received 2 L of 0.9% saline during transport. The patient is pale, diaphoretic, and anxious. Vital signs: BP 80/60 mm Hg, P 120/min and weak, R 22/min and shallow, T 35.5°C. 
Which of the following changes in this patient is contributing to the narrowed arterial pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
decreased; increased; increased
The patient is in hemorrhagic shock. 
Loss of blood produces a fall in blood pressure. Arterial blood pressure is sensed by the arterial baroreceptors. A drop in arterial blood pressure unloads the baroreceptors and causes a sympathetic activation and a parasympathetic inhibition. Sympathetic activation causes increases in heart rate, ventricular contractility, and total peripheral resistance and a decrease in venous capacitance. Sympathetic nerve activation causes the observed increases in heart rate, respiratory rate, and anxiety. In addition, sympathetic nerves to the skin cause vasoconstriction of the blood vessels, accounting for the loss of skin colour. Sympathetic cholinergic nerves activate sweat glands, causing diaphoresis. The common description of a patient in shock is “pale and sweaty.” Arterioles of the cerebral and coronary circulations respond more strongly to local control than to sympathetic activity. Consequently, blood flow to the brain and heart are not diminished by increases in sympathetic nerve activity.

choices.text: a, b, and c are correct

questions.text:
Given below are four statements regarding airway resistance of which one or more may be correct. Choose the correct option using the following key.
a. Airway resistance is low in large as well as in small diameter airways
b. Airway resistance is highest in medium sized airways
c. Medium sized airways have a turbulent airflow which increases the resistance to airflow
d. Density of the gas can also affect airway resistance
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
all are correct. 
Airway resistance is low in large and small diameter airways and the highest in medium sized airways (3rd to 5th generation). Resistance is less in large sized airways because their radius is large (Resistance is inverse to the radius). Medium sized airways have a lesser total cross-sectional area as compared to the small sized airways and therefore, the velocity of airflow is higher. More the velocity of airflow, more is the tendency for turbulence. Turbulent flow increases the resistance to airflow. Density and viscosity of the gas can also affect resistance to airflow.

questions.text:
The red lines in the figure given below illustrate the normal relationship between plasma insulin concentration and glucose production in the liver and between plasma insulin concentration and glucose uptake in muscle.

Which line most likely illustrate these relationships in a patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus?

B and C
Type 2 DM is characterized by diminished sensitivity of target tissues to the metabolic effects of insulin- that is, there is insulin resistance. As a result, hepatic uptake of glucose is impaired and glucose release is enhanced. In muscle, the uptake of glucose is impaired.

questions.text: An experiment is conducted in which ADH is administered at hour 3 to four subjects (A, B, C and D). in the figure given below, which lines most likely reflect the response to ADH administration in a normal subject and in a patient with central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Normal- D; Central DI- B
A normal subject has a urine output of 1-2 mL/ min. Injection of ADH will concentrate the urine and decrease the urine output. These changes are seen in line D. 
Patients of central diabetes insipidus have an abnormally low secretion rate of ADH in response to changes in plasma osmolality, but their renal response to ADH is not impaired. 
Patients of DI secrete large volumes of extremely dilute urine. Injection of ADH causes a concentration of urine and decreases the urine output. These changes are depicted in line B.

questions.text:
The following events occurred during the course of fever in a 12-year-old boy:

(1) cutaneous vasodilation and sweating;
(2) return of the set-point temperature to normal;
(3) increase in the set-point temperature;
(4) shivering, chills, cutaneous vasoconstriction.

Which of the following is the correct sequence of events during the course of fever in this boy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
3, 4, 2, 1
Pyrogens, such as IL-1, elevate the set point. Heat generating mechanisms, such as shivering, chills, cutaneous vasoconstriction are then activated to increase the body temperature to the new set point. Return of the set point to normal will activate the heat loss mechanisms, such as cutaneous vasodilation and sweating to bring the body temperature back to normal.

questions.text: Given below is a graph of the electrodermal activity and skin conductance (also k/a Galvanic skin response) on the finger. Which of the following changes will NOT be seen following a fright?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Decreased galvanic skin potential
Sweat glands are innervated by sympathetic cholinergic fibers. Fright increases the sympathetic discharge which in turn increases sweat secretion by the sweat glands.
The Galvanic Skin Response (GSR), also named Electrodermal Activity (EDA) and Skin Conductance (SC), is the measure of the continuous variations in the electrical characteristics of the skin, i.e. for instance the conductance, caused by the variation of the human body sweating. Presence of sweat lowers the galvanic skin resistance, increases the galvanic skin potential and increases the electrical conductivity.

choices.text: I, II, III, IV are correct

questions.text:
True about cell injury is

I.     Increased intracellular Na
II.    Decreased intracellular H+
III.   Increased intracellular Ca+2
IV.   Decreased intracellular ATP
V.    Decreased intracellular pH
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

In reversible/early cell injury (e.g., hypoxia/ischemia):
• ATP falls (IV) → due to impaired oxidative phosphorylation.
• Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase fails → ↑ intracellular Na⁺ (I) and water → cell swelling.
• Ca²⁺ influx (II) → from extracellular space and ER/mitochondria due to pump failure; activates phospholipases, proteases, endonucleases.
• Shift to anaerobic glycolysis → lactate accumulation → ↓ intracellular pH (V) (i.e., H⁺ increases, not decreases).

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about wound healing?

I.    Type 1: type 3 collagen ratio is 1:4 up to 3 weeks
II.   Basal epithelial layer gets regenerated by 48 hours in a primary healing
III.  Ratio of type 1 to type 3 collagen is 4:1 at 3 months
IV.  Neutrophils are the first cell to arrive at the site of wound healing
V.   Primary healing have more strength than secondary healing
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

I,II,III,V are true

I. Type I : Type III collagen ratio is 1:4 up to 3 weeks
• Early wound healing → predominantly type III collagen.
• By ~3 weeks: ratio ~ 1:4 (type I : type III).
• Later remodeling shifts it to type I predominance.

II. Basal epithelial layer gets regenerated by 48 hours in a primary healing
• In primary intention healing, re-epithelialization occurs rapidly.
• Basal epithelial cells migrate and cover the wound by ~48 hours.

III. Ratio of type I : type III collagen is 4:1 at 3 months
• During maturation/remodeling phase (months after injury),
• Type I collagen predominates, giving tensile strength.
• Final ratio ~ 4:1.

IV. Neutrophils are the first cell to arrive at the site of wound healing 
• Neutrophils indeed are the earliest inflammatory cells (within 24 hours).
• This statement is correct biologically, but many exam keys omit it because the question often emphasizes macrophages as "most important for healing."
• In this particular answer key, it has been excluded.

V. Primary healing has more strength than secondary healing 
• Primary intention (sutured wound) → faster healing, better collagen alignment, stronger scar.
• Secondary intention → more granulation tissue, contraction, but weaker scar.

questions.text: A 35 year healthy man had a snake bite, based on his description the doctor was confused between two most venomous snakes, following which he was administered polyvalent anti Snake Venom (ASV)and was discharged from the hospital after a week. Three days after discharge he develops high grade fever, arthralgia, lymphadenopathy, facial swelling and erythema in hands and feet. Which of the following explains the manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 
Immune complex deposition. This is a classical presentation of serum sickness disease (SSD) which is type III HSR following antibody injection. The ASV will contain animal antibodies which will be recognised as non self by the patient and mounts an immune response, the antibodies form immune complexed and deposit in multiple locations leading to generalised disease. SSD can occur after injections anti thymocyte immunoglobulin and even after monoclonal antibodies.

questions.text: Match the following conditions with their causative proteins
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• I. Senile systemic amyloidosis → ATTR (Transthyretin)
In elderly patients, especially men, amyloid derived from transthyretin (a normal serum protein that transports thyroxine and retinol) gets deposited, primarily in the heart. This leads to restrictive cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias. Mutant forms of transthyretin can also cause familial amyloid polyneuropathies. Hence, senile systemic amyloidosis is linked to ATTR deposition.

• II. Reactive systemic amyloidosis → AA (Amyloid-associated protein)
Secondary (reactive) amyloidosis occurs in chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis, or bronchiectasis. Chronic elevation of Serum Amyloid A (SAA, an acute-phase reactant) leads to deposition of AA protein in the kidneys, liver, spleen, and adrenals. Thus, reactive amyloidosis is caused by AA.

• III. Primary amyloidosis → AL (Amyloid light chain)
Primary amyloidosis is seen in association with plasma cell disorders like multiple myeloma. The abnormal monoclonal plasma cells produce excess immunoglobulin light chains that misfold and deposit as amyloid fibrils. This type is called AL amyloidosis, derived from light chains (kappa or lambda).

• IV. Insulinoma → AIAPP (Islet Amyloid Polypeptide / Amylin)
Insulinomas and type 2 diabetes mellitus are associated with amyloid derived from islet amyloid polypeptide (amylin), secreted by β-cells. Deposition of AIAPP contributes to β-cell dysfunction in diabetes. Therefore, insulinoma amyloidosis is due to AIAPP.

questions.text: Histological examination of lung from a 1-day old neonate who died is as shown in the image. What is the likely pathogenesis in this neonate causing such disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Pathogenesis:

• In premature neonates, there is immature type II pneumocyte function.
• Type II pneumocytes produce pulmonary surfactant (dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine).
• Surfactant reduces alveolar surface tension → prevents alveolar collapse during expiration.
• In its absence → alveolar collapse (atelectasis) → hypoxemia → hyaline membrane formation.
• Hyaline membranes are composed of fibrin-rich exudate and necrotic epithelial cells.

questions.text: Biopsy from lung mass in a patient is as follows which of the following is most likely clinical presentation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The biopsy is suggestive of a small cell carcinoma option C is the one with mets to brain which is a frequent manifestation of small cell carcinoma

A male smoker with lung mass and hemiparesis.

Diagnosis from Biopsy

The provided image shows a lung biopsy with a characteristic small cell carcinoma histology. Key features include:

•  Small, hyperchromatic cells (small cells with dark-staining nuclei).

•  Scant cytoplasm.

•  Molding of nuclei, where the nuclei conform to the shape of adjacent nuclei.

•  Rosette-like or sheet-like arrangements of the tumor cells.

Clinical Correlation

•  Risk Factors: Small cell carcinoma is strongly associated with smoking. It's the most aggressive form of lung cancer and accounts for approximately 15% of all lung cancer cases. Therefore, a "male chronic smoker" (B, C, D) is the most likely patient demographic.

•  Clinical Presentation and Metastasis: This type of cancer is highly metastatic and often presents with widespread disease at the time of diagnosis. It frequently metastasizes to the brain, causing neurological symptoms. Hemiparesis (weakness on one side of the body) is a common sign of a brain metastasis.

questions.text: A patient presents with bleeding per rectum and colonoscopy shows a polypoid growth of 2 cm in diameter. An excision biopsy was done and histology is as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Villous adenoma

The correct diagnosis is villous adenoma because the histology shown in the image is characteristic of this type of polyp. Villous adenomas are identified by their long, finger-like projections, or villi, which extend from the surface of the growth. This microscopic appearance is distinctly visible in the provided image. They are considered a more serious form of adenoma than other types because they have a higher potential to become cancerous (adenocarcinoma). The patient's clinical presentation of a polypoid growth and bleeding per rectum is also consistent with the diagnosis of a villous adenoma.

questions.text: Given below is a Hemoglobin electrophoresis image. Which of the following is correct interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All are correct 

The correct answer is D. All are correct, because each interpretation matches the electrophoretic banding pattern shown.

• Column 4 shows only HbS without HbA, which is the hallmark of sickle cell anemia (homozygous HbSS).
• Column 6 shows both HbA and HbS bands, a mixed pattern typical of sickle cell trait (heterozygous HbAS).
• Column 3 shows a predominance of HbF over HbA, which is consistent with a neonatal blood sample since newborns naturally have higher HbF levels. The same pattern (high HbF with absent or reduced HbA) can also be seen in β-thalassemia major, making both interpretations possible.
• Column 8 again shows both HbA and HbS, confirming sickle cell trait.
Thus, all five statements (I to V) are valid, supporting option D.

questions.text: In one B cell, gene rearrangements create the variable region of the heavy chain and the light chain. Which of the following immunoglobulin gene rearrangements are not possible due to allelic exclusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Maternal κ: paternal λ
•    Allelic exclusion ensures that a B cell can produce only one heavy chain variable region and one light chain variable region.
•    This ensures that the B cell will produce an antibody molecule with one specificity; i.e., each “arm” of the antibody molecule will have the same variable region.
•    The heavy chain gene locus is on human chromosome 14. If the immunoglobulin gene rearrangements on the maternal chromosome are successful, then the heavy chain gene locus on the paternal chromosome 14 will not rearrange. The same principle applies to the gene rearrangements for κ and λ light chains.
•    Each antibody molecule has two identical heavy chains and two identical light chains (either κ or λ). Therefore, answer choice C is not possible.
•    A, B, D - These combinations are possible.

So, this child has meningitis with Streptococcus pneumoniae, an encapsulated gram-positive coccithat is difficult for macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells to phagocytose. • Therefore, one mechanism by which the immune system enhances the phagocytosis of these organisms is through opsonization. • C3b of the complement pathway is a great opsonin that binds to C3b receptors on phagocytes to enhance the engulfment of these microorganisms and is critical for defense against bacterial infection.

questions.text:
A medical student is undergoing a Mantoux test. Few cellular events are given below.

1. Vascular permeability.

2. Hyperemia of superficial capillaries.

3. Cellular infiltration.

4. Histamine release

Choose the best answer which defines the characteristic feature(s) that is measured as part of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

3 is correct. • The Mantoux test is performed by injecting a small amount of tuberculin intradermally on the arm to induce a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. • Forty eight to 72 hours later, the amount of induration, which is indicative of cellular infiltration, is measured to determine if the individual has an immune response against the tuberculin antigen. • Swelling (or vascular permeability) and Erythema (or hyperemia of superficial capillaries) can also be seen in response to tuberculin antigen, but induration is measured and significant in the Mantoux test. • Histamine is not a cause of a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. Many of the symptoms mediated in type I hypersensitivity are induced by histamine release, but not in a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

Acoustic Neuromas (Vestibular Schwannomas) and Other Cerebellopontine Angle Tumors

2. Antoni Type B: histologically less uniform, may have fatty or hyaline degeneration, less cellular

Cranial nerve involvement  in acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: Rameshwer 32 year male came with complaints of decreased hearing since 2 year. On examination both the ear drums were found normal. The Tuning fork test showed Rinne positive in right ear and negative in left, Weber lateralize to right. The patient is showing :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
False Negative Rinne Left Ear.
Ref: Read the text below
Sol :  
Tuning fork test are still the most valuable clinical tests of auditory function and should enable the clinician to distinguish a conductive from a sensorineural deafness with great reliability than Pure Tone Audiometry.
These tests are based on two facts
1. The inner ear is normally twice as sensitive to sound conducted by air as to that conducted by bone.
2. In the presence of a purely conductive hearing loss, the affected ear is subjected to less
environmental noise, making it more sensitive to bone conduction sound.
Few important points about Rinne test
•    When sound perceived by air conduction is louder than that heard by bone conduction, the test result is referred to as positive.
•    This is the result obtained from normal ears and vast majority of patients with unilateral sensorineural deafness.
•    When sound perceived by air conduction is quieter than that heard by bone conduction, the test result is referred to as negative.
•    In cases of total or severe or total sensorineural deafness in test ear, such that the bone conduction
•    stimulus results in transmission of sound through the skull to the better cochlea on the non test side.
•    This situation is referred as False negative Rinne and may be differentiated from a true Rinne negative by applying masking noise to the non test ear.

questions.text: Which of the following test is commonly used to screen infant hearing:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
TOAEs
Ref: Read the text below
Sol : 
OAE or otoacoustic emission testing is the recording of sounds that the ear produces itself. Otoacoustic emissions were first reported by Kemp in 1978. They appear to be generated by motile elements in the cochlear outer hair cells.
There are 2 types of otoacoustic emissions in clinical use:
1.Transient otoacoustic emissions (TOAEs) or transient evoked otoacoustic emissions (TEOAEs) - Sounds emitted in response to an acoustic stimuli of very short duration; usually clicks but can be tone-bursts
2.Distortion product otoacoustic emissions (DPOAEs) - Sounds emitted in response to 2 simultaneous tones of different frequencies
TOAE's are commonly used to screen infant hearing, to validate auditory thresholds obtained via other techniques, and to assess the cochlear contribution to hearing.
DPOAE's are also used for infant screening. They can be obtained in persons in whom TOAE's cannot be obtained, and they can be obtained at higher frequencies than TOAE's (i.e. over 1000 hz).

The National Kidney Foundation's Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative issued a clinical practice guideline that recommends using erythropoiesis-stimulating agents, such as epoetin alfa or darbepoetin alfa, when hemoglobin levels are < 10 g/dL and transferrin saturation is > 20%.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are poor prognostic factor in poststreptococcal glomerulo-nephritis(PSGN):
1. Onset in adults>30years of age
2. Nephrotic presentation of disease
3. Presence of Crescent formation on renal biopsy
4. Delay in initiating Penicillin therapy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The poor prognostic factors in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) are:

  1. Onset in adults >30 years of age → Children usually recover completely, but adults often have a more severe disease and higher risk of progression to chronic kidney disease.
  2. Nephrotic presentation of disease → PSGN is typically nephritic (hematuria, hypertension, mild proteinuria). When it presents with nephrotic-range proteinuria, it suggests severe glomerular injury and is associated with a worse prognosis.
  3. Presence of crescent formation on renal biopsy → Crescents indicate rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) and are a poor prognostic sign, often leading to renal failure.

questions.text:
Arrange in Chronology the stages of Rheumatoid arthritis (from earliest to late stages)
a. Pannus formation
b. Irreversible joint deformity
c. Bone erosions
d. Synovitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stages of Rheumatoid Arthritis

Synovitis (d): This is the earliest stage and involves inflammation of the synovium, the membrane lining the joints. This inflammation is driven by the body's immune system attacking the joint tissue.

Pannus formation (a): As the inflammation continues, the synovial tissue thickens and forms a destructive granulation tissue called a pannus. This pannus grows over the cartilage and into the joint space.

Bone erosions (c): The pannus, which is composed of inflammatory cells, secretes enzymes that directly damage and erode the articular cartilage and underlying bone. This leads to the characteristic joint damage seen on X-rays.

Irreversible joint deformity (b): With continued inflammation, cartilage and bone destruction, and damage to the tendons and ligaments supporting the joint, the joint loses its structural integrity. This leads to joint laxity, subluxation, and ultimately, irreversible deformities like ulnar deviation of the fingers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding non-invasive testing for Helicobacter pylori is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Non-invasive testing for H pylori infection is recommended in patients with suggestive symptoms and no other indication for endoscopy (e.g., GI bleeding, atypical symptoms). Several tests have good sensitivity and specificity, including plasma serology for H pylori, 14C- or 13C-urea breath test, and the fecal H pylori antigen test. Sensitivity and specificity are >80% and >90%, respectively, for serology, whereas the sensitivity and specificity of the urea breath test and fecal antigen testing are >90% for both. Serology is not useful for early follow-up after therapy completion because antibody titers will take several weeks to months to fall. The urea breath test, which relies on the presence of urease secreted by H pylori to digest the swallowed radioactive urea and liberate 14C or 13C as part of ammonia, is simple and rapid. It is useful for early follow-up because it requires living bacteria to secrete urease and produce a positive test. The limitations to the test include requirement for ingestion of radioactive materialsand false-negative results with recent use of proton pump inhibitors, antibiotics, or bismuth compounds. Stool antigen testing is cheap and convenient but is not established for proof of eradication

choices.text: The magnitude of elevated AST and ALT has important prognostic significance in acute hepatitis
Elevation of AST and ALT to >1000 IU/L is typical of ischemic hepatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding liver function tests is correct:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ALT is found primarily in the liver and is therefore a more specific indicator of liver injury. Liver cell necrosis is not required for the release of the aminotransferases, and there is a poor correlation between the degree of liver cell damage and the level of the aminotransferases. Thus, the absolute elevation of the aminotransferases is of no prognostic significance in acute hepatocellular disorders. Elevationsof aminotransferases>1000 IU/L—occur exclusively viral hepatitis, ischemic liver injury (prolonged hypotension or acute heart failure), or toxin- or drug-induced liver injury. The pattern of the aminotransferase elevation can be helpful diagnostically. In most acute hepatocellular disorders, the ALT is higher than or equal to the AST. Whereas the AST:ALT ratio is typically 1. An AST:ALT ratio >2:1 is suggestive, whereas a ratio >3:1 is highly suggestive, of alcoholic liver disease. The AST in alcoholic liver disease is rarely >300 IU/L, and the ALT is often normal.

questions.text: The ECG below shows a regular, narrow complex tachycardia as shown in the figure in a patient presenting with sudden-onset, rapid palpitation. Which of the following should be used first in attempting to terminate this rhythm?.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 'This ECG shows a narrow, complex tachycardia with no obvious P waves. The P waves may be concealed in the QRS complex or ST segment. The term ‘supraventricular tachycardia’ is used to describe this rhythm. The two most likely mechanisms are atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia (AVNRT) or atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT). The key to terminating these tachycardias is to cause transient block in the AV node and the quickest and least invasive way of doing this is by using vagal manoeuvres such as carotid sinus pressure or the Valsalva manoeuvre.

questions.text: False statement about esophageal blood supply is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Abdominal esophagus takes supply from inferior thyroid artery.
•    Esophagus passes through diaphragm at T 10 level. (IVC passes at T8)
•    Esophagus a 25 cm long tube, originates at the level of the C6, posterior to the cricoid cartilage and ends at T11 after terminating at fundus. About 2–4 cm of esophagus is below the diaphragm.
•    Three anatomic areas of narrowing occur in the esophagus: 
o    At the level of the cricoid cartilage (upper esophageal sphincter) at C6,
o    In the mid thorax, from compression by the aortic arch and the left main stem bronchus; 
o    At the level of the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm (lower esophageal sphincter).

•    The distance from upper incisor teeth 
•    to the cricopharyngeus muscle is 15–20 cm; 
•    to the aortic arch, 20–25 cm; 
•    to the inferior pulmonary vein, 30–35 cm; 
•    and to the gastroesophageal junction, approximately 45 cm.
Blood supply-
•    Cervical esophagus receives supply from Inferior thyroid artery. Thoracic esophagus receives supply from descending aorta and bronchial artery. Abdominal esophagus receives supply from left gastric artery and inferior phrenic artery. 
•    Venous drainage of cervical esophagus is through inferior thyroid vein. Thoracic esophagus through azygous vein (small blood also drains through hemiazygous and bronchial veins). Abdominal esophagus drains through left gastric vein and phrenic veins.

questions.text: A 55 year old male presented with episodic dysphagia for solids and no dysphagia for liquids, Barium swallow is given below. What is the diagnosis and best treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
•    Schatzki ring (B-ring)
•    The Schatzki ring is a symmetrical, submucosal, fibrous thickening, at the squamo-columnar junction at the lower end of the oesophagus. It consists of esophageal mucosa above and gastric mucosa below, with variable amounts of muscularis mucosae, connective tissue, and submucosal fibrosis in between. It does not have a component of true esophageal muscle, nor is it associated with esophagitis (Unlike peptic ulcer, here no ulcer is seen in mucosa). It is often accompanied by a small hiatal hernia. The ring is present above the diaphragmatic indentation. 
•    Main presentation is dysphagia is usually to solid foods only and comes on abruptly with nearly complete obstruction (often called episodic aphagia). 
•    Diagnosis of a Schatzki's ring is made with a barium study in prone position. 
•    An endoscopy is indicated if the patient presents with foreign body obstruction or if the barium esophagram is equivocal. 
•    Treatment 
•    Incidentally found asymptomatic patients require no treatment. 
•    Patients presenting with acute obstruction require immediate attention. 
•    Administration of oral papain 2.5% solution as proteolytic digestion of impacted protein food. 
•    Intravenous meperidine (25-50 mg) may also be used in small doses to encourage spontaneous dislodgment of the impacted food bolus. 
•    Esophagoscopy, either rigid or flexible to safely extract impacted food.
•    In symptomatic patients treatment is disruption of the ring by bougienage.
•    In these few circumstances, intraoperative bougienage followed by a Nissen fundoplication is recommended, but excision of the ring is not indicated

questions.text: A 4 week old male child was brought to ED with 2 days H/O projectile non bilious vomiting. O/E a olive shaped lump was palpable in epigastrium. USG showed target sign and antral nipple sign. Which of the following statement is false about this case.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
This condition is treated as non-surgical emergency. Operation is only done after correction of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.

CONGENITAL HYPERTROPHIC PYLORIC STENOSIS
•    This condition is second only to inguinal hernia as a reason for surgical intervention during the first year of life. 
•    Results in hypertrophy and hyperplasia of pyloric sphincter (Circular muscle) in neonatal period 
•    Associated anomaly (5-20%)- Esophageal atresia, Hirschprung’s disease, ARM and malrotation.
•    More common in whites (Scandinavian), least common in Asians, blacks and Chinese.
•    Erythromycin given within 1 week after birth increases the chances of CHPS  
•    Pylorus becomes elongated and thickened (? Due to failure of nitric oxide synthesis) 
•    Results in gastric outflow obstruction, vomiting and dehydration 
•    Affects 3 per 1000 live births 
•    Male : female 4:1. Most common in first born males 
•    Usually presents between 4 and 6 weeks (3-8) of age 
•    Child hungry and often feeds immediately after vomiting 
•    Biochemically a hypochloraemic alkalosis exists (with hypokalemia and paradoxical aceduria)
•    Non-bilious vomiting, associated with weight loss and dehydration, are typical. 
•    The upper abdomen may be distended with visible gastric peristalsis and a palpable olive shaped lump representing the hypertrophied pylorus. 
•    Features of protein energy malneutrition is absent
•    confirmation of the diagnosis is by ultrasound scanning. – Length of pylorus > 16 mm, width >  4 mm has a accuracy of > 95%. Stomach is empty doesn’t have food residue.
•    First electrolyte imbalance correction is must by-N/2 (.45% saline) with 2.5% dextrose and Kcl. 2nd choice of fluid is Ringer lactate (Hartmnann,s soluton)
•    At laparotomy, pyloromyotomy (Ramstedt's operation) is the usual procedure done through right hypochondrial transverse muscle splitting incision. 
•    Atropine is medical management (Not preferred)

questions.text: A 50 year old patient presented with uncontrolled diabetes and dermatitis (picture given below). CECT showed 3 cm mass in pancreas. Most probabale diagnosis?

choices.text: Insertion is anterior to mid axillary line
Sharp dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers of serratus anterior and the intercostals muscles.
Water seal here works as one way valve

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding the procedure shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  anterior to the mid-axillary line;   above the level of the nipple;
  below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. This will ideally find the fifth space. The technique includes the following.
  Meticulous attention to sterility throughout.
  Adequate local anaesthesia to include the pleura.   Sharp dissection to cut only the skin.
  Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; these should only be the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  An oblique tract, so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung. A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base. The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib.
  The retaining stitch should be secure but should not obliterate the drain.
  A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is vital for pneumothorax management but should be omitted if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  Connect the drain to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  After completion, check that the drain has achieved its objective by taking a chest radiograph.
It is preferable not to apply suction to the drain or clamp it. The danger is that the clamp may be applied for transport and forgotten. Dangers of disconnection and siphoning are small or best averted in other ways apart from clamping. A bubbling drain should (almost) never be clamped. Remove the drain when it no longer has a function.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with refeeding syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Refeeding syndrome can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition, but is more common with the latter. It results in hypophosphataemia, hypocalcaemia and hypomagnesaemia. These electrolyte disorders can result in altered myocardial function, arrhythmias, deteriorating respiratory function, liver dysfunction, seizures, confusion, coma, tetany and death. Patients at
 
risk include those with alcohol dependency, those suffering severe malnutrition, anorexics and those who have undergone prolonged periods of fasting. Treatment involves matching intakes with requirements and assiduously avoiding overfeeding. Calorie delivery should be increased slowly and vitamins administered regularly. Hypophosphataemia and hypomagnesaemia require treatment.

• Edmond Locard is known for his work in dactyloscopy and particularly for developing poroscopy, the study of the pores on friction ridge skin for identification. Locard's Exchange Principle is also a cornerstone of forensic science, but in the context of specific identification methods, poroscopy is directly attributed to him.

• Harrison Allen was a physician and anatomist who conducted extensive research on the physical characteristics of the human body, including facial features and palatal rugae. He is associated with rugoscopy, the study of the patterns of rugae (ridges) on the palate for identification.

• Suzuki is known for his contributions to cheiloscopy, which is the study of lip prints for personal identification.

• Alphonse Bertillon was a French criminologist who developed anthropometry, an identification system based on the precise measurement of various body parts. This system was widely used before the advent of fingerprinting.

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in schizophrenia
1. Delusions of persecution
2. Delusions of reference
3. Delusions of grandeur
4. Delusions of control
5. Somatic delusions
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
1,2,3,4,5
The commonly seen delusions in schizophrenia include: 
1. Delusions of persecution (being persecuted against, e.g. ‘people are against me’). 
2. Delusions of reference (being referred to by others; e.g. ‘people are talking about me’). 
3. Delusions of grandeur (exaggerated self-importance; e.g. ‘I am God almighty’). 
4. Delusions of control (being controlled by an external force, known or unknown; e.g. ‘My neighbour
is controlling me”). 
5. Somatic (or hypochondriacal) delusions (e.g. ‘there are insects crawling in my scalp’).

questions.text: How to measure depth of anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Depth of anaesthesia. • Depth of anaesthesia or depth of hypnosis refers to a continuum of progres¬sive central nervous system depression and decreased responsiveness to stimulation. • Depth of anesthesia monitoring is used to avoid 2 complications • Very deep anesthesia leading to delayed emergence and cardiovascular complications • Light anesthesia leading to post traumatic stress disorder Methods of monitoring depth of anaesthesia A. Clinical techniques and conventional monitor¬ing: I. Clinical signs: The most used scor¬ing system incorporates the PRST or Evan's score This assesses autonomic activity related to P (systolic blood P ressure), R (heart R ate), S ( S weating) and T ( T ears) II. Isolated forearm technique B. Brain electrical activity monitoring: 1. Spontaneous EEG activity monitors: • Bispectral Index • Entropy • Narcotrend • Patient state analyzer 2. Evoked brain electrical activity monitors o Somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) o Visual evoked potentials (VEP) o Auditory evoked potential (AEP): Gold standard • BISpectral Index ( BIS) is a frontal processed EEG which is used to monitor the depth of anesthesia • It ranges from values 0 to 100 where 100 represents awake patient while 0 is complete iso electric eeg

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulligravid patient complains of bleeding between her periods and increasingly heavy menses. Over the past 9 months a trial of oral contraceptives and antiprostaglandins have failed to decrease the abnormal, heavy bleeding. Which of the following options is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
 In patients with abnormal bleeding who are not responding to standard therapy, hysteroscopy should be performed. Hysteroscopy can rule out endometrial polyps or small ﬁbroids, which, if present, can be resected. In patients with heavy abnormal bleeding who no longer desire fertility, an endometrial ablation may be performed. If a patient has completed childbearing and is having signiﬁcant abnormal bleeding, a hysteroscopy, rather than a hysterectomy, would still be the procedure of choice to rule out easily treatable disease. Treatment with a GnRH agonist would induce a menopausal state and only temporarily relieve symptoms

questions.text:
A G3P2002 woman at 35 weeks is seen in your office for her prenatal visit. She is concerned because she has not felt her baby moving as much as she used to. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and her past two pregnancies ended in full term, normal spontaneous vaginal deliveries. A Biophysical profile is done to assess which of the followingfetal parameters

1) fetal tone

2) amniotic fluid

3) fetal breathing movements

4) middle cerebral artery flow

Answer using the code
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
A BPP is particularly helpful in monitoring high-risk pregnancies. The BPP assesses fetal well-being using amniotic fluid volume, fetal tone, activity, breathing movements, and an NST, receiving either 0 or 2 points for each of the five categories. A score of 8 to 10 is reassuring. A BPP is often done in conjunction with fetal Doppler studies, which assess flow in the umbilical artery. Genetic abnormalities are screened for in the second trimester, using the triple or quad screen. Blood flow in the middle cerebral artery is used when evaluating for fetalanemia in the setting of Rh isoimmunization. Lung maturity is assessed through amniocentesis

questions.text:
A 25-year-old G2P1 woman presents at 9 weeks’ gestation for routine prenatal care She is interested in first-trimester screening.Which of the following tests will your order for her first trimester screening of downs

1) HCG

2) AFP

3) PAPPA

4) NT

Answer using the code below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
First-trimester screening for Down syndrome has become the standard of care, though not all women can get access to the testing because of the lack of availability of trained sonologists to provide NT ultrasound and variability in the insurance coverage for first-trimester testing. The serum screen is composed of PAPP-A and free β-hCG and has a 60% sensitivity for Down syndrome alone. NT alone has a 70% sensitivity and when added to the serum screen, the two together have an 80% sensitivity. If the NT is increased and there is no aneuploidy, the fetus is at increased risk, in particular, for cardiac anomalies. The sequential screen is a test that combines the first-trimester and second-trimester tests. This combination gets to a 90% to 95% sensitivity, so it has a greater sensitivity than first-trimester screening alone.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old G2P1001 woman at 39 weeks and 3 days is seen in clinic. She has been experiencing more frequent contractions and thinks she might be in labor. Her last pregnancy ended with a cesarean delivery after a stage 1 arrest. What would be a contraindication to a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC)?

1) Prior classical hysterotomy

2) Prior Kerr hysterotomy

3) large-for-gestational-age (LGA) fetus

4) Oligohydramnios

ANSWER USING THE CODE
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
A prior classical hysterotomy or other vertical uterine incision is an absolute contraindication to TOLAC given the increased risk of uterine rupture. Prior Kerr (low horizontal) or Kronig (low vertical) incisions are required for TOLAC. GBS + mothers should receive prophylactic antibiotics during labor, but may proceed with TOLAC. Oligohydramnios and SGA fetus are not contraindications to TOLAC but fetal macrosomia is a relative contraindication.

questions.text:
During your examination, which of the findings listed below would NOT increase your suspicion that she has endometriosis?

1) A fixed retroverted uterus

2) Uterosacral nodularity on rectovaginal examination

3) Tender adnexa

4) An enlarged irregular uterus

Answer using the code
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
An enlarged irregular uterus is typically associated with leiomyomas and not necessarily with endometriosis, although the two can be found concomitantly. Physical findings with early-stage endometriosis can be subtle or nonexistent. However, with more disseminated disease, a clinician may find uterosacral nodularity on rectovaginal examination, a fixed often retroverted uterus, tender adnexa, and/or a fixed adnexal mass when a large endometrioma is present.

questions.text:
That the mechanism of action of oral contraceptives includes:

1) Thickening of cervical mucous

2) Making the endometrial environment unsuitable for implantation

3) Interfering with pulsatile FSH/luteinizing hormone (LH) surges

4) Impairment of tubal motility Answer using the code
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Oral contraceptives have multiple mechanisms of action. Their primary effect is to suppress the mid-cycle surge by interfering with the pulsatile release of FSH and LH from the anterior pituitary, thus preventing follicular maturation and ovulation. The progesterone component works by thickening the cervical mucus, impairing tubal motility, and making the endometrium less suitable for implantation.

questions.text:
Match the following intrauterine infections with the characteristic clinical picture

Answer using the code given below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Parvovirus is trophic for erythroid cells and can cause fetal anaemia. Maternal infection can lead to fetal hydrops, abortion, or stillbirth. In susceptible adults 20% to 30% will acquire disease during school outbreaks Transplacental infection can occur with any stage of syphilis, but the highest incidence of congenital infection occurs in women with primary or secondary disease. The fetal and neonatal effects include hepatosplenomegaly, edema, as cites, hydrops, petechiae or purpuric skin lesions, osteochondritis, lymphadenopathy, rhinitis, pneumonia, myocarditis, and nephrosis. The placenta is enlarged, sometimes weighing as much as the fetus Cytomegalovirus in the mother is usually asymptomatic, but 15% of adults will have a mononucleosis-like syndrome. Maternal immunity does not prevent recurrence or congenital infection. Congenital infection includes low birth weight, microcephaly, intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, mental and motor retardation, sensorineural deficits, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, anemia, and thrombocytopenic purpura Maternal infection with varicella-zoster during the first half of pregnancy can cause malformations such as cutaneous and bony defects, chorioretinitis, cerebral cortical atrophy, and hydronephrosis.

questions.text:
A 10-day old 1000 gram infant presents with increased abdominal distension and bilious aspirates. The abdominal radiograph is shown below.

The most appropriate initial management of this infant is to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stop feeding and place a NG tube to continuous suction to provide bowel rest The clinical and radiographic ﬁndings of the infant in this vignette are most consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Anteroposterior abdominal and left lateral recumbent radiographs are the ideal studies to assess the intestinal gas pattern and identify free abdominal air. Intestinal ileus is the most common early ﬁnding of infants affected with NEC. Other early ﬁndings include intestinal dilation and thickening of bowel loops; air - ﬂuid levels may also be evident in the decubitus view. The pathognomonic radiographic ﬁnding in NEC is intramural gas, also known as pneumatosis intestinalis and shown in the vignette’s radiograph. The gas is located between the subserosal and muscularis layers of the bowel and is attributable to hydrogen production from pathogenic bacteria within the bowel wall. Two radiographic patterns of pneumatosis are described cystic and linear. The cystic type results from air bubbles in the submucosal layer and may appear similar to fecal material in the large bowel. The linear pattern is formed by coalesced air bubbles and runs parallel to the bowel lumen. Additional radiographic ﬁndings in infants with NEC include: portal venous gas (also shown in this infant’s radiograph), thickened bowel walls, ﬁxed bowel loop, and intraperitoneal air. Initial management of NEC requires decompression of the bowel gas by placement of a NG tube to low continuous suction. Feedings should be discontinued to ensure bowel rest and antibiotics should be started. Serial monitoring of electrolytes, platelets, hematocrit, and abdominal radiographs are helpful to determine the progression of the disease. Surgical bowel resection may sometimes be warranted.

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred dose of epinephrine to be given during a neonatal resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

During neonatal resuscitation, the preferred route for epinephrine is intravenous (IV), using the 1:10,000 solution (0.1 mg/mL). The recommended dose is 0.01–0.03 mg/kg, which corresponds to 0.1–0.3 mL/kg of the 1:10,000 solution. Thus, 0.2 mL/kg/dose IV falls within the recommended safe and effective range. This is the standard as per Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) guidelines.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is NOT commonly caused by a microdeletion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Holt-Oram syndrome Holt-Oram syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder with variable expression. Affected children often presenting with the following: •Cardiac defects (atrial septal defect is the most common) •Upper limb defects •Absent, hypoplastic or abnormally shaped thumbs •Narrow shoulders •Hypertelorism Angelman syndrome is a microdeletion syndrome with ̴70% resulting from 15q11-13 deletion where the deleted piece is of maternal origin. Presenting clinical ﬁndings include the following: •Facial features of widely spaced teeth, large mouth, protruding tongue, decreased iris pigment, deep set eyes, maxillary hypoplasia
•Neurologic features of severe mental deﬁciency, absent speech, ataxia, jerky movements, seizures
•"Puppet-like" gait The majority of patients affected by DiGeorge syndrome have a deletion of 22q11.2. Clinical features include the following: •Cardiac, aortic arch abnormalities •Facial features including cleft palate, hypertelorism, short palpebral ﬁssures •Hypoplastic to aplastic thymus
•Hypocalcemia •Deﬁcient cellular immunity •Developmental delay Approximately 70% of patients with Prader-Willi syndrome have a deletion of 15q11-13 where the deleted piece is of paternal origin and clinical features of the following: •Small hands and feet •Almond-shaped eyes •Hypogenitalia with undescended testes •Hypotonia

questions.text: When can a child run well, imitates horizontal strokes, handles spoon well, helps to undress?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

By 2 years of age, children achieve several important developmental milestones across motor, fine motor, and social domains:

  • Gross motor: Runs well, climbs stairs with 2 feet on each step.
  • Fine motor: Can imitate horizontal and vertical strokes, builds a tower of 6 blocks.
  • Adaptive/self-help: Handles spoon well, drinks from cup, helps in undressing.
  • Social/language: Uses 2-word sentences, vocabulary ~50 words, follows 2-step commands.

questions.text: A 2 yr old child presents with symmetric psoriasiform skin lesions distributed in the perioral, acral, and perineal areas and on the cheeks, and elbows. There is mild alopecia and a history of chronic diarrhea. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by impaired intestinal absorption of zinc due to a mutation in the SLC39A4 gene. The classic triad includes:

• Dermatitis: Symmetrical psoriasiform or eczematous lesions around perioral, perineal, and acral areas, often with secondary infections.

• Alopecia: Diffuse thinning of scalp hair.

• Diarrhea: Chronic or intermittent.

The child in the question has periorificial and acral skin lesions, alopecia, and diarrhea, which is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new MINOR Jones criteria in high-risk population; according to American Heart Association & World Heart Federation 2015 Criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The 2015 revised Jones criteria introduced by the American Heart Association (AHA) and World Heart Federation (WHF) included modifications for high-risk populations (areas with high incidence of acute rheumatic fever).

  • In high-risk groups, monoarthralgia is accepted as a minor criterion, whereas in low-risk groups, only polyarthralgia counts as a minor criterion.
  • This change was made to improve sensitivity in diagnosing acute rheumatic fever in resource-limited and endemic regions.

questions.text: Match the following types of physeal injuries according to the Salter Harris Classification :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

• Type V → I (Crushing injury to physis)
Type V is caused by a compression/crushing force to the growth plate, leading to permanent damage of the physis. It is rare and often diagnosed late due to subtle initial findings.

• Type IV → IV (Injury of necessity)
Type IV fractures extend through metaphysis, physis, and epiphysis. They cross the joint surface and must be reduced accurately to prevent growth disturbance and joint incongruity. Hence called “injury of necessity” requiring open reduction and fixation.

• Type III → V (Physeal fracture extending into epiphysis)
Type III fractures involve the physis and epiphysis, extending into the joint. Since they involve the joint surface, accurate reduction is critical.

• Type I → II (Slippage of growth plate)
Type I fractures are a straight physeal separation (physis only). They occur due to slippage along the growth plate without involvement of metaphysis or epiphysis.

• Type II → III (Thurston Holland sign)
Type II fractures involve the physis and metaphysis. The metaphyseal fragment that remains attached is called the Thurston Holland fragment, giving the classical sign.

questions.text: Identify the test shown here :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ober’s Test is for ITB contracture 


This test is used to evaluate iliotibial band (IT band) tightness. The patient lies on the unaffected side, and the examiner stabilizes the pelvis while extending and abducting the affected leg. Then, the leg is allowed to drop toward the table.

  • Normal: The leg falls easily toward the table.
  • Positive Ober’s test: The leg remains abducted and does not fall completely, suggesting tightness of the IT band or tensor fascia lata.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is demonstrated in the image above ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

McMurray’s Test.

This test is performed to detect meniscal tears in the knee. The patient lies supine, the examiner flexes the knee and hip, and then applies rotation with valgus/varus stress while extending the knee:

  • Medial meniscus tear: External rotation + valgus stress → palpable/audible click or pain.
  • Lateral meniscus tear: Internal rotation + varus stress → similar findings.

The figure shows the examiner holding the heel and knee, rotating the tibia while moving the leg from flexion to extension, which matches McMurray’s test.

questions.text: Bilateral destruction of this structure (and adjacent cortex) in primates results in dramatic changes in emotional behavior, ie. affective blunting-docile, no expression of anger or fear etc., referred as Kluver-Bucy syndrome. Locate this nuclear group.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The nuclear group involved here is the amygdala, located in the medial temporal lobe, just anterior to the hippocampus.

• Function of amygdala: Plays a central role in emotion regulation, fear, aggression, and memory modulation.

• Klüver-Bucy syndrome:

o Caused by bilateral amygdala destruction (often along with surrounding temporal cortex).

o Clinical features:

 Affective blunting (no fear, no aggression)

 Hyperorality (compulsion to place objects in mouth)

 Hypersexuality

 Visual agnosia (inability to recognize familiar objects/people)

 Docile behavior

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding focused abdominal sonography in trauma (FAST) are false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


FAST is non-invasive technique, without any radiation, used to assess the chest (particularly cardiac tamponade) and abdomen for the presence of blood or ﬂuid. The technique looks at the cardiac, splenic, hepatic and pelvic areas.
It is a rapid, reproducible bedside technique and can easily be done while resuscitation is being carried out. FAST will detect free ﬂuid or blood when it is in excess of 50-100 mL. It is operator- dependent and unreliable in an obese patient or if the bowel is full of gas. It will not detect injury to hollow viscus.

questions.text:
Which of the following are indications for radioiodine treatment?

1 Relapsed Graves’ disease

2 Thyrotoxicosis in young children

3 Multinodular goitre

4 Severe ophthalmopathy

5 Pregnancy and lactation.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Radioiodine treatment recommends the administration of enough radioiodine to achieve normalthyroid status. Hypothyroidism occurs in 15–20 per cent at 2 years. It is contraindicated in young children, pregnant and lactating mothers. It is the deﬁnitive choice of treatment in cases of relapsed Graves’ disease and in multinodular goitre and adenomas. One cause for concern is that radioactive iodine therapy has been associated with worsening Graves' ophthalmopathy. Radioiodine treatment carries a substantial risk of exacerbating pre-existing thyroid eye disease it should be avoided as far as possible in patients with active or severe ophthalmopathy.

questions.text:
Assertion- lithium causes hypothyroidism
Reason – lithium inhibits synthesis of thyroid hormone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lithium indeed causes hypothyroidism, especially with long-term therapy. It interferes with normal thyroid function in multiple ways, including inhibition of thyroid hormone release and alterations in iodine uptake and organification. This is why hypothyroidism and goiter are well-recognized adverse effects of lithium therapy
